messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Care of sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: BTW, If anyone does feel the need to wax an iron tsuba, be careful to keep the wax out of the sukashi openings.  It ll get into any rust there and will not
messages.messageBody:
BTW,
If anyone does feel the need to wax an iron tsuba, be careful to keep the wax out of the sukashi openings. It'll get into any rust there and will not look right.

Overall, wax is better than oiling a guard (which really makes a mess), but it shouldn't be necessary for a well treated tsuba, at least in a moderate climate.

Jim

Another issue is " waxing " the tsuba.
I've heard many conflicting views on that............I suspect a lot
of people do that to give their tsuba that lustrous moist look, but
of course few will admit to that.
I have outbid a well known /knowledgable dealer on a can of old
japanese tsuba wax on e-bay........question is if the advance people
poo poo on waxing the tsuba then why he placed a bid ?

Naturally you guys will ask if I wax my tsuba.........hahahaa, yes
and no. I used to but I found out the wax does wear off so the
effect of the lustre is not permanent. I discovered a better way now,
no, it's not wearing it in your rear pocket ( for the SF residents ).

milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Care of sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Interesting story Ron, though less detail about sleeping with tsuba is fine by me :-). I think the important thing to remember is that if you are unsure, do
messages.messageBody:
Interesting story Ron, though less detail about sleeping with tsuba is
fine by me :-). I think the important thing to remember is that if you
are unsure, do what is safest, i.e a silk or cotton cloth will do little
damage so it should be fine just fussin over the tsuba that way.

I love reading the section in Tsuba, An Aesthetic Study on the mixtures
made up in the old days that were used to bake the patina in include Rat
dung, clay, blood ect.

Rich

Ron Hartmann wrote:

> A friend of mine who worked in a gym (sweated a lot) used to
> occasionally take one of my iron tsuba and wear it around his neck,
> day and night. Yes, he even slept with it! (Lord only knows...) Two of
> these tsuba took on a wonderful color within a month while another--it
> seems it was a later tsuba of a more dense/harder plate--did not color
> much. Like Cary's tsuba from years ago--tsuba in the pocket
> treatment--sometimes natural oils (juices) work, sometimes they don't.
>
> Ron
> STL
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Care of sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: A friend of mine who worked in a gym (sweated a lot) used to occasionally take one of my iron tsuba and wear it around his neck, day and night. Yes, he even
messages.messageBody:
A friend of mine who worked in a gym (sweated a lot) used to occasionally take one of my iron tsuba and wear it around his neck, day and night. Yes, he even slept with it! (Lord only knows...) Two of these tsuba took on a wonderful color within a month while another--it seems it was a later tsuba of a more dense/harder plate--did not color much. Like Cary's tsuba from years ago--tsuba in the pocket treatment--sometimes natural oils (juices) work, sometimes they don't.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: Care of sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... cleaning ... is dated ? ... hi Steve, Personally, I only clean the opening IF the rust distort the outline of the design but don t overdo it..........if
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "steven" <steven_88_2000@y...>
wrote:
> My thanks to Curran and Milt for answering my questions regarding
> care and cleaning of old sukashi pieces. Do your answers mean that
> you don't quite agree with Sasano-sensei's advice regarding
cleaning
> of the sukashi openings? Or is it that his advice here
is "dated"?
> Forgive my ignorance here... :o). Thanks again!
>
> Steve

hi Steve,
Personally, I only clean the opening IF the rust distort the outline
of the design but don't overdo it..........if in doubt best to leave
it alone.
Another issue is " waxing " the tsuba.
I've heard many conflicting views on that............I suspect a lot
of people do that to give their tsuba that lustrous moist look, but
of course few will admit to that.
I have outbid a well known /knowledgable dealer on a can of old
japanese tsuba wax on e-bay........question is if the advance people
poo poo on waxing the tsuba then why he placed a bid ?

Naturally you guys will ask if I wax my tsuba.........hahahaa, yes
and no. I used to but I found out the wax does wear off so the
effect of the lustre is not permanent. I discovered a better way now,
no, it's not wearing it in your rear pocket ( for the SF residents ).

milt

messages.subject: Care of sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: My thanks to Curran and Milt for answering my questions regarding care and cleaning of old sukashi pieces.  Do your answers mean that you don t quite agree
messages.messageBody:
My thanks to Curran and Milt for answering my questions regarding
care and cleaning of old sukashi pieces. Do your answers mean that
you don't quite agree with Sasano-sensei's advice regarding cleaning
of the sukashi openings? Or is it that his advice here is "dated"?
Forgive my ignorance here... :o). Thanks again!

Steve
